description:
I always come by this area of the city but surprisingly I have never discovered this cafe until now! It is by a corner on Geary and it is so easy to skip this place because of other cafe and food choices nearby. 

Honestly speaking, this is such a decent cafe where I will take a second experience right after my first! Their menu is simple but quality also comes along! Their price is more than just!  The setting of this place is also study/working-friendly, and I have spent a good afternoon working on my computer here without feeling uneasy.  It is also a good place if you need extra stimulus from looking out the window, you will see lots of interesting things happen in this neighborhood.
author: Shuyi L.

description:
They were closed for months and fairly recently reopened. I had assumed that they'd jack up their prices, offer $5 toast, and have man-bunned hipster d-bags taking the orders. Instead, we're treated to a wonderful remodel with no downside that I can see.

Decent coffee and food at reasonable prices. The wi-fi works well. Really can't complain.
author: Chuck G.

description:
My favorite coffee shop.  Just a block from my work. Better deal than the closer Pete's Coffee, and the ladies always remember my usual order.

Unfortunately they closed for remodeling with no word on when they might reopen.  Please reopen!
author: Miriam G.

description: Royal Ground is back from renovation! It's cuter than ever! They removed the worn and slumping sofa to replace new all matching new chairs and tables. The cashiers and barista section has been rearranged. It works! I appreciate the original artwork left on the walls. Coffee and food still taste the same.
author: Jen L.

description: Love this place! Huge food selection, great coffee, friendly staff, and a great place to work (wifi+plugs) with plenty of seating! Definitely better than the big chains :) Service is great too!
author: Shiran D.

description: Great price. Food and drinks are prepared perfectly. Suitable for studying, catching up with friend or just grabbing something quick to eat.
author: Youzhu S.

description: Everything was awesome! It's great to have full breakfast available in the neighborhood, not just bagels. The only downside is it took a really long time. It seems like they should have one more person working in the kitchen.
author: Theresa H.

description: I just moved to the city and Royal was the first place I chose for breakfast. Without looking it over at Yelp, I am surprised at the rating given I had a yummy classic breakfast. It's a great place to bring your laptop and work or just read a book and enjoy some coffee. I would definitely bring friends here for a quick morning bite.
author: Marlene F.

description: After remodel it feels nice and clean and new, the added food options are great and I feel like the customer base has gotten nicer too. Less people just sitting and bothering you and not buying anything. Great peaceful place to work. The service has always been great. Awesome alternative to other cafes that are too dirty, and too full, and too much in the area. Decent prices great food. We get just egg and gooey cheddar and spinach breakfast bagels, with yummy iced coffee, never fails. But they now have full breakfast meals as well. I grab fruit bowls when I'm in a rush. :)!
author: Katie B.

description: Came to get a hot chocolate and pie. The male worker has way too much attitude. He gets very catty and sassy. He also makes the WORST beverages and sandwiches out of all of the staff. 4 stars for the ambiance and food. But 2 stars for being disrespected all while I am helping your business thrive by supporting it. I started going to Angelinas on California. They are pretty great.
author: Mitch C.

description: After being closed for half a year for a remodel, Royal Ground Coffee came back even better. The staff is very nice, the shop is very clean and inviting, and the service is top-notch. One of my favorite coffee shops in the Richmond district because of the amount of space you have as well. Definitely recommend.
author: John F.

description:
I'm reviewing as someone who works in the area and popped in for a breakfast sandwich. No, I didn't order coffee, but I still would like to review for those who, well, might not be looking for coffee.

Ambiance: quaint, clean, and comfortable. There is nice seating with tables that I could see would be great for meeting with a friend or studying.

Food: disappointing. I ordered the breakfast sandwich on an everything bagel. The bagel itself was fine and was toasted. However, the cheese was American cheese and the egg was microwaved. I should have just gone to McDonald's for this kind of quality (to be honest, I'd prefer an Egg McMuffin to this). It didn't taste good. 

Service: Terrible. I'm not expecting formal dining room service, but a smile, friendly tone, or even a thank you goes a long way. I know it was 6:15 am, but I'm a patron and the negative attitude coupled with the microwave egg sandwich will not bring me back. Any time the man taking my order asked me a question (which bagel, salt and pepper?) he had his back to me so I couldn't understand him. When I asked him to repeat himself, he seemed extremely annoyed. Plus, he didn't wash his hands between serving the customer before me and handling her money and making my sandwich.
author: Susan G.

description: A wonderful cafe with great wifi and a lot of comfortable spaces in which to set up for a while. Nothing about the menu or the coffee drinks is spectacular, but they do a great job with what they have: On my latest visit I wound up with a hot apple cider that I presume began as powder, but it came out with several freshly submerged cinnamon sticks. Another fine tribute to the tradition of old SF. They do it right here.
author: James D.

description: Who would have thought! Delicious Apple salad, with grilled hot chicken, and a strong iced latte for ~$14. Glad I played it healthy and resisted bagel temptation!
author: Jessica L.

description: 5 dollar minimum for cards (but there is an atm inside). Sweet grandparents' house atmosphere, although it smells kind of weird. Service isn't very friendly. Good hours, open until 10.
author: Briana G.

description: Food is OK and price is reasonable. However, service is bad. I'm not expecting very excellent service because it is just a small coffee place. But, can you please look happier and be more patient? The lady who took my order looks very angry for some reason. And she is talking with another girl while taking my order, that I need to repeat my order items for 3 times. Then, I asked her is the restroom needs a key or it is just occupied. She was not patient at all and just pointed to the key hanging on the wall, saying 'Key, can you see the key?', which sounds kind of annoyed.
author: Li D.

description:
Frappé is like milkshake's cousin.
Did my Avocado Frappé bring all the ladies to the yard?
No.
But it brought a cute nonhipster* chick from the bus stop to the door.
To the bus stooooop! To the door! To the door!

*jk I heart hipsterettes.
author: Dan B.

description: Awesome cafe that I'd love to visit again to have a nice cup of coffee and a slice of cheese cake! The interior is relaxing and comfortable. This is a perfect place for me to wind down and enjoy a great food!
author: Sujin K.

description: I needed a pick me up and this place had coffee. It worked! Also needed a place to finish some work and was able to use their wifi here. I like the couch and the dim lighting. Go here and be amazed.
author: Sean R.

description:
Best matcha latte I've ever had.  She recommended soy milk.  (I read that casein in cows milk takes away from some of the health benefits of green tea.)She didn't explain why she recommended soy, but I figured she must've also knew what I did.  But whatever, it was so delicious!
I also enjoyed how relaxed the environment was there.  I wish I lived closer, I'd go there more often.  I'll definitely go back.
author: Marvella W.

description: This is my favorite neighborhood cafe to bring my laptop and get work done. The wifi is fast, and the food / coffee is cheap. I've never had trouble finding a seat either. Coffee is ~$2, and sandwiches run $5-7. I've spent entire Saturdays and Sundays here. Don't know what I'd do without it. Only gripe is that it's a tad dirty - cobwebs in window, smelly bathroom. Not a big deal though.
author: Shane W.

description:
Was wandering around Clement  St to Geary for 40mins looking for a healthier option breakfast.  Stumbled upon RG exasperated reading  another blah coffee  shop menu.  Steps into the doorway you arrive at a counter filled w oat cakes $2.25, raspberry oatmeal bars, Aussie bites, fresh made salmon spinach feta quiches and pasties/turnovers salads, salmon lox bagel capers red onion and you know you HAVE arrived at the right location.  Menu is not yuppified which would actually be my go to but RG is solid on food.  However, Royal Grounds is in need of a groundskeeper...Decor is grimy, chipped painted tables  mural walls old wooden floors that long to be the highlight of a much desired makeover, single unisex bathroom.

That salmon lox bagel $5.50 however is AMAzing, my first ever ordered and now my marker. Thicker 1/4" freshest cuts of seemingly house made, non commercial salmon (it is tho? I guess??, I asked..."ordered from THE company??" , still I'm returning on my 3-day stay!

$1.55 reg 12oz coffee  $1.95 Americano  $1.95 Mighty Leaf teas!! $2-3 slice red velvet carrot cakes. Come get Royal!
author: Lu L.

description:
Bless this place for their abundance of electrical outlets! It's usually pretty quiet in here, so a nice place to work, especially when your wifi at home is acting real hungover. 

This isn't normal coffee shop wifi. You know, the kind where one dude's Netflix'd episode of GOT is ruining everyone else's life. Nay! Somehow this place has figured it out, and no matter how many people are sucking the wifi teat at once, there is always strong connectivity.

Y'all make one helluva BLT too.
author: Alexis H.

description:
There are plenty of cafes in the Sunset I can go to this day but I sometimes I want to venture to the other side of the park. Also this just happens to be across the street from Sharetea so thats another plus. Came here to do some studying for a final. Was mildly crowded but there were plenty room for seating. I ordered house coffee and Apricot oatmeal bar. The coffee was what you expect from drip coffee, plain. Though I didn't mind the bland taste of the Apricot bar it tasted too dry and had a chewy texture. 

What is the best thing about this place? IMO its the sweet location on Geary being near so many businesses and restaurant. What is not so great about this palce? For sake of brevity I'll label them in points and give short description: 

Not so great: 

-Dry not so fresh pastry
-Slow internet. Gets bogged down easily with few users online.
-Discourteous staff. When you engage any of the baristas you immediately get the vibe they don't want to be there serving you, and they don't want to be there period. 


There is a lot of better cafes in the area I'd recommend people go to where staff is friendly and ambiance is much nicer.
author: Jude N.

description: Quick reliable service, clear offerings and clear pricing, perfect for a morning or mid-day pit stop!  I have not tried the sandwiches but only standard bagels which are pretty standard but meet par.
author: Patrick O.

description:
Wow. I come in here every so often when I'm in the City and get some coffee. It's not bad! I'm in here working right now, using MY OWN internet. The place is 2/3 EMPTY, and the lady just said I had to order something or leave. RUDE! I'll go to a Starbucks from now on.
I understand why this place is empty most of the time!
author: Brent R.

description:
I'm not into gourmet food when I'm looking for a cafe.  My priority is:

1. wi-fi
2. spacious with lots of tables/chairs/outlets
3. near a bus stop

all in that order.  I go there to surf the web and relax while listening to my laptop music for a few hours after I do my shopping on Geary.  If it has great food, great but it's not a priority with me.  The same goes for the people behind the counter - as long as they're not doing things that are totally taboo like giving you rotten food, then it's fine since "small talk" chitchat is not a priority with me either.  I've gone many times to Royal Cafe and the experience has been very good to great.  It's spacious enough that you don't feel squished/claustrophobic next to everyone else.   It isn't very scenic and you won't think it's very clean because they can't afford to just easily finance a million dollar cafe makeover like Starbucks, but the cafe is fine with me. 

The people behind the counter aren't the most sociable but they aren't mean either - it's just how most Asians are.  Most Asians are introverts and cautious.  If they sound bossy, especially Asian females, it's just confidence (and the fact their family owns the cafe and/or the main workers in the cafe) and a need to get their tasks done quickly and should not be an assumption of arrogance.  I have never had a problem talking to them about my order, getting good service, asking about the wi-fi, asking to use the restroom,etc.  When you're in line to make your order, get your order ready asap and don't waste their time while other customers in the rest of the line are waiting to be serviced too.  Asians usually chitchat with friends they already know, not total strangers.

The coffee's not the best but they have smoothies, teas, italian sodas, regular store beverages, dessert cakes/pies, sandwiches, bagels, omelets, gyros, etc.  They have sofas as well as tables/chairs.  Right in front of it is the 38 bus stop which is a plus with me.  

The noise level can be medium-high in the afternoons but level off in the late afternoon to night times.  They do accept CC but I think there's a $5 or $10 minimum.  They're one of the few cafes on Geary that stay up as late as 10pm and there's no "2 hour maximum" (for wi-fi time before you get kicked off to force you to buy more stuff) which is common in some cafes.......cough... Peet's!......  If i'm going to be at Royal Cafe for more than a couple of hours, I usually order $20 worth of stuff anyway all in 1 order.
author: Frugal C.

description:
I got the Vanilla Frappe. It was good.  

I snagged a primo spot in the corner bench seat with table. Studied for a solid 4 or 5 hours. People here are so nice. I'll be back!
author: Ali B.

description:
I would really like to give this place more stars. Unfortunately, I just can't do it. If there's one thing we learned from Ted Nugent, it's that just because we want something to be awesome, that doesn't make it true.

Some of the other reviewers say the service is amazing, but I have been several times and that's just not the case. They aren't unfriendly, but they sure aren't sociable. The food is good, but there is nothing distinctive about it. Other little things take away from a next-level cafe experience, like the pre-cut "cream cheese patties" on their bagels and the ingredients throughout their menu that aren't always the freshest. 

Bottom line: this is a relaxed, solid little cafe. Good coffee, good wi-fi, good food, good service. Nothing to write home about, but it's the only place in the area that is at least average for all of these things at once.
author: Derek B.

description: I ordered a Thai ice tea from here. It was awful. Taste like water. The environment is good and pretty, but the restroom is so dirty and smelly.
author: Connie H.

description: A comfortable Cafe to watch the world go by as people, buses and cars rush down Geary Street. Perfect place to grab a nice white chocolate mocha, freshly grounded coffee, breakfast bagles or yummy list of tasty sandwiches.  An ideal place to study, chit chat with friends or read a novel.  I go here for the studying for hours and hours, no inturruptions and always helpful staff.
author: Eui O.

description: Got a thai iced tea and a spinach pocket. Nice menu with sandwiches and a good drink list. Located on Geary.
author: Denise C.

description: I was searching for a coffee place that was open late at night, having to make the long trip back to Menlo Park and feeling in need of a caffeine stimulus. This was the only nearby place still open, but I found it rather charming. They have free wifi, excellent oatmeal cookies, and decent coffee. The lady at the counter was also very friendly and helpful and I rather took to the un-chainlike vibe of the place.
author: Steve B.

description: Love this local coffee shop in my neighborhood, it has a bit of old school charm interior, bunch of seatings and outlets. Nice for just having a coffee and reading, or working with a laptop. I like the variety of beverage they have, so sometimes at night I just grab a freshly made smoothies. They also serve light food like sandwiches and bagels, which I like a lot since I am not big on heavy stuff. The only thing I'd say is one time there was a customer sitting close to me mumbling almost all the time, a little scary to me (didn't expect this from a coffee shop :/)
author: Jaclyn C.

description: I got the Thai iced tea: it was refreshing on a dazzling warm day, but unfortunately the main ingredient was ice. Wished there was deeper flavor in the tea. Since it was to go, I didn't get to relax in the charming shop, but the murals and homey touches were nice.
author: Nancy Y.

description: How do you review a coffee place, when you didn't order coffee? Yelp keeps prompting me, so here goes...we split a veggie bagel, it was great, probably the best I've ever had. Was a first date and we're still together, so now it's kinda' nostalgic for us. We pop in occasionally and order up a breakfast bagel.
author: Flix N.

description:
Mission: To work on several important research documents that are due asap.

Vibe: There is a beautiful mural that wraps around the walls with an interior layout that is soothing to the eyes. Great lighting comes though its large windows with a nice view of the Geary foot traffic. Nice green plants are stacked by the window with cute tables and two giant sofas to underscore a relaxed atmosphere. The crowd is mostly made of college students and local residents to make it a worthy spot for people watching. Background music: 90's jam, including the King of Pop.

Drinks: The soy chai was not the best but I was totally blown away by their house coffee. As a regular drinker of soy Americano, I was kept awake by their small house drip till 4am last night. Very cool.

Food: They made me a very tasty toasted bagel with peanut butter and jam. One of my favorite comfort foods during stressful times.

Service: Humble, modest, friendly, and down to earth. I was greeted every time upon entering and they went out of their way to thank me whenever I leave. They also have their regulars with whom they know by name. Free wifi with plenty of sweet spots. Very cool.

Reflection: To be honest, I didn't really want to give this place a chance due to lackluster experiences at other Royal Grounds. However, I was able to find good reasons to come back after each visit and this is why I'll be returning sooner than you think. I consider this café to be my urban oasis whenever my world is in the state of mad chaos.

Final rating: 5 stars for all the intangibles this place offers.
author: Daniel L.

description:
There is one young woman in particular who is very rude and thinks she owns the place. Very bossy to her co-workers and short with customers asking about menu details. 

The food is okay and the coffee is very acidic but good if you are into that.

I have been going to this place for about 8-9 years but she causes such a negative experience that I really have been trying to find reasons NOT to spend money there. To bad, it used to be such a nice place.
author: brian s.

description:
Came here first time for coffee and pie, bad idea!!!
First no one gave us attention for the first 5 minutes .
Pie is stale and the americano I ordered was just plain coffee. I ordered "for here" but she put the coffee in a paper cup. I asked her for a cup and she reached for a glass, hello, really!!!
Never again
author: Konstancia M.

description:
When I need to be productive, Royal Ground Coffee is my new spot to hit up. I don't have much to do in the way of studying anymore since I just finished grad school. However, now that I've entered the more stressful phase of the imminent job search, you'll probably find me here filling out my work and education history for the 100th time (or at least it feels that way). 

One of their biggest selling points is the free, un-limited wi-fi! And with all my job apps being online, this is something I need, not just something I want/prefer (as was the case during my nerdy student days). I haven't gotten coffee here yet, but I can vouch that the Thai Iced Tea and White Hot Chocolate are some pretty quality tasting drinks. The bagel with cream cheese, capers, and lox is good too. But then again, an establishment has to be pretty lousy to mess up on something as simple as that. 

The place has a slightly dumpy look to it, namely due to the couches with green sheets thrown haphazardly over them. However, I like it that way. Makes the place feel more cozy and homey. I like the sunny, yellow walls and murals of European villages too. And the multitude of windows overlooking the bustle of Geary provide good visual stimulation for those times when I find myself zoning out. 

All in all, I really like this place. This job search has got me feeling like I'm wandering in a pitch-black tunnel, but for all that I've been able to accomplish here, Royal Ground Coffee just might be that flashlight I've been looking for.

Anyways, I hope I can stop coming here soon. I really don't want to be a regular. Because as cute and cozy as this place is, I want to be working in my career field, not sitting here trying to break into it. 

4 stars for now. I'll up it to 5 if I can manage to get hired somewhere desirable.
author: Natasha H.

description: The food is pretty basic, but sometimes I get a sandwich there because I am too lazy to make my own damn sandwich. The guy who works there, though, he is a grump. I don't like ordering from him because he may be soulless. A soulless heap of a human.
author: Nancy D.

description:
HEALTH CODE WARNING - DO NOT EAT HERE

I walked in an saw an older man behind the counter working frantically and ordered a royal bagel.  I saw that the man was accepting cash from several customers and using the cash register without washing hands or using gloves, and then preparing the food.  I politely asked him to wash his hands or use gloves and he violently threw the bagel sandwich across the room and screamed at me to leave.  You should not eat here for fear of getting sick or coming across an incredibly rude and belligerent staff.
author: Michael B.

description:
To the girl behind the counter: Do you even work here? Do you even like the people that come into this cafe thereby paying your wages? Wait. Wait. Do you even like people? 

Also, there's a sign posted that says "Free wireless is for customers only." So I ask what the password is. There's no password. So really... I can come in here and not bother talking to your surly counter girl and sit in the corner and use your wifi? Which, btw, I'm not even using because you happen to be around a Comcast hotspot.

But alas, you are within spitting distance of my apartment and I need a place to study so... I'm stayin. I'm finishing my coffee.
author: Karva S.

description:
Absolutely amazing. I was going to a different place with a friend thinking they had actual food besides coffee and just ended up here. We're now calling this out place. Cutest feel to it; it was very warm and inviting. The food (chicken sandwich) was great, and they're carrot cake was great. The coffee was okay, just maybe a little too much caramel syrup. But the coffee itself was very good. All reasonably priced. A small iced coffee with caramel syrup, chick sandwich with avocado and a chunk of carrot cake only cost me $12. That's a full meal with dessert right there (plus they had good sized portions. Not too much, just enough for as much as I was paying.) 

This is a great place, and conveniently located next to USF. Definitely going back. I would give this a 4.5 but I can't. They only reason so was cause the syrup in the coffee wasn't 5-star worthy. Next time, I'll ask for light syrup. 
PS: syrup in coffee and avocado on sandwiched is a bit extra. 

Great experience, great place. Highly recommended.
author: Samantha A.

description:
Not a bad place to be for your local Starbucks boycotter. They are much cheaper and their food is decent. I love the paintings on the walls.

Free Wi-Fi! Doesn't get any better than that! It's a comfortable atmosphere with plenty of outlets for laptops... the perfect place to go studying or Facebook-stalking... whichever you choose to do with your time.
author: Sara K.

description:
The cheapest date I've ever been on was at this Royal Ground.  The guy ordered an iced coffee ($1.50) for himself and told me that I could have whatever I wanted for myself.  

(Thinking to myself: Really?  Anything on this menu?  Dang, you're a big spender, huh?  Everything on the menu is less than $10.  Wait, don't be like that.  Maybe he didn't bring that much money.  Be considerate.  Order something small.  Just order the same thing as him.) 

Me: I'll have an iced coffee, too.

We go over to where the stirrers, lids, and creamers are and my date proceeds to pour and use all of the remaining creamer into his coffee.  I go to pour some cream for myself (just in case he really didn't use all of it), only to discover that yes, indeedy, he did.

Me: Hmm, OK.  Well, I can drink my coffee black, I guess. It's OK.

My date: (Stupid grin, no apologies, no nothing).

After about an hour of some meaningless non-revelatory conversation, our date is over.  Hug, hug, smooch, smooch, blah, blah, whatever, whatever...

I don't see that guy anymore.  I still go to Royal Ground for iced coffee, though.  Hold the cream.  I like it black.
author: Danielle O.

description: Coffee is pretty good and cheaper than most places.  The 2 ppl who work in there seem like they work their tails off.  Banana Bread is good too!
author: Chelsey G.

description:
I like it here the way a normal person might like sitting at a hippie artist friend's house and enjoying a nice cup of coffee. It isn't antiseptically clean the way a chain might be, and yeah, you might find couches draped with sheets and newspapers strewn about, but that's half the charm! This cafe has a worn-in, homey feel and a sweet mural of a generic Italian town. You sort of just sink into the couches. I half expect a cat to wander by and sample my drink. The food is probably all from Costco, but the latte was good, and most importantly, it is a comfortable, warmly lit place to just sip away and chat with friends.

Important note: I visited once in the afternoon on a weekday and there appeared to be a table full of mafia (Russian? Armenian? no idea) men gathered at an outside table playing dominos. Fascinating.
author: Diane Y.

description:
This place has slowly ground on my nerves (pun intended) until I finally feel the need to write an update. I've been here several times, it's my neighborhood cafe. At first, I really liked the place -- and with good reason: good ambiance, good coffee. As a student, what you need to do gets done.

However, over time, and with more and more negative experiences, I have been subjected to hours and hours of awful 90s songs (trust me, not a music snob here), dirty tables and unappetizing pastries bought at costco and resold for more expensive, and the snarky attitude of the owner. So tired of being approached at 9:55 and being told "we're closing." Yeah, I figured. And thanks for reminding me rudely as if I was going to keep you.

It's hard to describe exactly how rude the owner is. I'm an easygoing person and generally let a lot of things slide. But I'm also in law school and remember coming here especially at 7am because i needed to get work done. The internet wasn't working, and I told the owner. She shrugged. 15 minutes later, I went up to her again, and she told me that sometimes it takes a while to turn on. She was absolutely rude and didn't seem to understand that I came to use the internet to finish a paper, not to sit around and enjoy the 7am silence. First time in my life I've ever left a place in anger, vowed never to come back, and since haven't.

Given that it is not an every day occurrence, two stars, Royal Grounds.
author: Asaf K.

description: I ordered a hot chocolate. It's was terrible. Taste like water, syrup and alcohol. It was the worst, I've ever had.
author: Olga F.

description: Love it here! Nice place to get work done and the service is always friendly. I can always find a place to sit and an outlet for my laptop. Coffee isn't the best I've ever had but the prices are reasonable. I love that they have Mighty Leaf tea and the baked goods/cakes are pretty tasty (love the carrot cake).
author: Semuteh F.

description:
I avoid this place as much as possible ...

The one girl behind the counter can't smile, look at you or say "hi" or even tell me the cost - thank god I can see the price because I don't want to talk to her scowled face!

THen there is their mom (?) who barks at me from behind the counter.  It's OBVIOUS I'm not ready to order since I am rummaging through my bag and I'm TEN FEET FROM THE COUNTER!!!!

good luck!
author: Janet J.

description:
I try to like this place, but it's hard. The food and drinks are decent and reasonably priced, the staff is friendly if you are friendly to them, but I can't get comfortable enough to get serious work done here. 
Maybe it is the space itself, long but not deep, almost every seat feeling close to the door.
Maybe it is the Musak that most people try to drown out with their headphones.

There are neighborhood people here, from the elderly couple who sit in the window to the many students attached to headphones and laptops. 

But there are also a fair amount of creepy people who come in pretty regularly. If they were coming in to buy things it would be fine, but mostly they come in to root through the trash, spread their stuff out on the tables, yell, and disrupt the place.
The staff are polite, I'd say too polite in a lot of cases, when really they should encourage non-patrons to go on their way.
author: Rachel M.

description: Not pretension. Comfy couches, plenty of space, and good, inexpensive coffee.
author: AJ F.

description:
A fast walk to beat the impending doom of seriously condensation charged mist from the coast charged me right across the Golden Donut (closes at 8:00) and telepathy prompted me about Peet's closing at the same time as well.

I ran in to get a large Breve Latte extra hot and while we stood there waiting for my lovely creamy drink, the slice of dark chocolate cake of chocolate doom ensnared my thoughts and eyes: I was drawn to it like a moth to a flame.  While the nice barista was making my hot drink, another person ran over to ensure that I had been assisted by the desserts display.  Talk about awesome service.  Dang.

The slice of cake was as follows:

four layers of sinfully moist dark chocolate cake, sandwiched alternating lovingly between a spatula worth of creamy sweet dark chocolate frosting.  Add on another coating of this frosting on the top and patted with large dark chocolate shavings.

One bite and it was soooooooooo creamy and thick, I could not speak:  caught without words.  If it were not for my perfect coffee, I would have remained mute from the chocolate delight between my lips.  We took turns sharing bites, walk away, take a sip of coffee.  And repeat the dessert dance.

Lovely lovely stuff.  These updates are making me very very happy.
author: Miika M.

description: I'm sorry but this place could be SO much better. It's in a great spot, good light, nice size, etc. but EW...why is it so unnecessarily dirty in here? It literally smells like an old couch and bathroom is gross. The food/drink are subpar and service is less than friendly. Did I mention the smell?
author: K P.

description: It's cheap, it's comfy, and they let you stay as long as you want (I've done a solid 8 hours in one sitting and nobody ever bothered me). It's the perfect study place with lots of seating, lots of outlets, quite atmosphere, and a variety of people stopping buy for some cheap and tasty coffee. I have a soft spot for this place. It's not the best food or the best coffee but it's the best experience.
author: Victoria F.

description: Great coffee (lattes and mocha) great pastries. Nice seating area with couches chairs and tables. Fairly quick service
author: Zoe D.

description:
In some ways I felt like I was sitting in a greenhouse.  I just got that vibe.  

I asked for an iced green tea.  I ended up getting hot green tea.  Okay...

The teabag was Kirkland brand.  Alright...  

The banana nut bread was good, but I felt like it may have also been from Costco.  Ugh.
author: Rachelle P.

description: Staff was friendly, bathroom was clean. Chai tea was the worst I've ever had. Do not order.
author: Courtney E.

description: This is a cute place to get some work done (free wifi) and have a smoothie, coffee or pastry. It's conveniently located on Geary and the 38 Geary stops right in front.
author: Carlos A.

description:
In theory, this place is terrible. The chai latte is watery and the food is not something you'd typically find when trying to treat yourself. It's either store-bought or microwaved. 

But I can stay here for hours and be comfortable. There's a bathroom and a place to plug in my laptop.  There are comfortable couches and good people. And the soy white mocha is rather strong and delicious... and hell, I do love Costco pumpkin pie.
author: Elizabeth A.

description:
I have yet to write a yelp review, but have worked in several food facilities where good and mediocre reviews were highly appreciated.  I am a fan of Royal Grounds Coffee since moving to San Francisco- my intention is not to bash the franchise. It's this particular location I'm very concerned about. 

As we walked in, a woman greeted us rudely and did not look pleased to see us or to to be there. I ordered 2 salads which were 5.50 each, a raspberry bar and a vegan cookie. My friend decided she did not want the vegan cookie, but astonishingly she refused to give her change for the cookie. She simply shook her head and said she could not because she was "too short" in her register. Looking around at the 20+ people in the cafe I can assure you that at least one of them paid in cash and she had bills less than the 20 I gave her. I got involved in the conversation but she kept saying that my friend had the option of buying something else on the list, so to avoid conflict my friend replaced the cookie with a green tea of the same price. As I sat down a bit flustered, I felt overcharged  because it was 19.50 and I had not received a receipt- nor offered one. The line was long so I shrugged it off. 

A few minutes later as we were waiting for salads a man came in about in his late 20s attempting to pay for something in cash as well, and she told him the same thing that there was no change left in the register after he had received the item. He was fine at first then quickly became furious and grabbed his correct change out of the tip jar. He stormed out of the cafe and she followed him shortly after. Returned without any luck of catching up with him and looked like she just saw a ghost. A girl about 18, was next in line. She paid for a coffee with bigger bills and something crazy happened. I guess she decided she liked this person, or knew her personally and opened the register and gave her correct change in many different bills!!!! I could not believe my eyes. When the salad came ten minutes later it was bland as hell. But I had already lost my appetite.

The woman who worked here was clearly stealing from people, and trying to con them into not minding when she didn't give proper change and using her language barrier as an excuse to why she couldn't explain why the register wouldn't open. I confronted her at the end for being dishonest and she turned stone cold and kept repeating the register is short the register is short. 

I write this because I believe in good, honest and effective customer service. It doesn't matter what type of business you are running or how much money you make per day. For something as simple as a coffee shop, the owner or manager or barista or whatever she was should cares about the care and happiness of her customers over everything. 

Bad people do not deserve your business. Consider yourself warned
author: Savannah A.

description: Lots of space but lots of flies. How unfortunate. House coffee is alright, it has the burnt taste of Starbucks but I don't mind that.
author: Varun K.

description:
I didn't realize this was a chain.  It doesn't have the feeling of a typical coffee chain.  The decor is a funky mish-mash of grandmotherly floral prints and city murals.  Not only do they offer free wi-fi, but they have plenty of power outlets so you could stay for a long, long time.  It's a comfy, spacious place to settle in with coffee (the lattes are pretty good) and a sandwich or pastry.  With huge windows, it stays light inside.

I had an egg sandwich that I liked because it came with fresh, crispy lettuce and a slice of juicy ripe tomato.  There isn't much of a kitchen area to cook anything but they offer a pretty good variety of sandwiches.

Too bad it's cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description:
The drip coffee is decently strong and relatively smooth, free wifi is always a plus, prices are very reasonable, if not downright cheap, and the atmosphere is cozy. Why only three stars? 

Despite the overall charm of Royal Ground, the interior felt dirty, grungy, and clammy. The tables aren't wiped down regularly and while I felt somewhat comfortable, I also felt a bit uneasy, as one feels in a dirty restaurant while waiting for the food. 

Likewise, I was also a bit peeved about the soy milk. Because I don't drink milk, I always ask for a tiny amount of soy milk to use as creamer. Every coffee shop I've ever been to has always obliged at no extra charge. Royal Ground? No. The counter person obstinately told me that it would cost 65 cents (more than fifty cents) for the extra soy. I wanted to tell her that I was merely asking for soy as creamer (especially since soy is comparable in price to half and half) and NOT for a large amount like in a latte or mocha. But no. I was very disappointed. Fortunately the coffee was smooth and not particularly acidic, and my stomach escaped unscathed.

Royal Ground could be a really fabulous coffee shop if only they had friendlier employees, wiped down the tables, and did something to make the place feel cleaner.
author: Melissa K.

description: Friendly people behind the counter and the steamed milk was skillfully steamed in my latte, nice furniture to spread out and read or use your computer. I had just stopped in to get a latte really quick so I would like to come back and stay a while in the nice atmosphere.
author: Bertamus R.

description: The cream cheese crumble cake was ideally moist with a crunchy and sacory berry crus. The espresso was typical, mass sourced, not anything which struck the palate. Overall a reliable cafe
author: Aashay T.

description:
So much potential!

The Royal Grounds Blend coffee is actually quite good - too bad they never serve it and only seem to have Max's Blend brewing and in beans for purchase (I only had the Royal Grounds Blend once). The other good thing is it isn't hard to find a seat because no one frequents the place and you can always work/ study here as needed with no issue. WiFi has generally been pretty decent. Prices are pretty good too.

The things to be improved. Service is certainly wanting. The frequent buyer system doesn't seem to work but the person behind the counter can't be bothered to fix it or help. Also, I ask for the medium and am given (and charged) for the large coffee because the person says that's what most people mean when they order the medium (???). Service is not unfriendly but it is clear the folks behind the counter want to do the least amount possible to complete your order. (I run a business and I hate to say it, if I had an employee with that attitude, I would have to let them go).

I also am not a fan of the food. I've had a sandwich and thought I put together a better one (too many onions, mustard, and pickles usually so certainly ask for going 'light' on those items to get the right ratio if you get a sandwich here.) The baked goods are actually quite bad and should be avoided. The chocolate biscotti I had tasted like it was lemon biscotti dunked in generic chocolate. The Mexican Mocha cookie I had tasted old (like the saran wrap it was in) and the chocolate chips in it were barely edible. 

The place itself can also use a good scrub. I cringe to put my bag on the floor and try to find a chair on which to place it. Everything is sort of dull and faded - but hey - certainly a change of scenery from the ultra modern coffee bars, I guess.

To wrap up, 
If you are looking for excellent coffee with good food in the neighborhood, go to Velo Rouge (Blue Bottle), 50/50 (Ritual), or the Russian Bakery on Balboa (Ritual) but seating is iffy at all three and prices are reflective of the coffee/ food.

If you are looking for a cheap place to grab a cup of coffee and sit for a while, this is the place.

(And if you want a bite to eat, what the hell are you doing here - walk down the street and get some awesome Asian food in the Richmond!)
author: Parag G.

description:
I've spent many hours here studying and I don't have many bad things to say
One of my favorite things is that the food and drinks are REALLY reasonably priced. Small coffee is $1.45. Beef and Lab gyro is $4.25 (the meat is microwaved yes, but its a generous portion and still delicios). BLT for $3.95 with nice thick cut bacon (again, microwaved but not a big deal to me. Pretty much all the sandwiches and salads are under 5 bucks. Much cheaper than the other Royal Grounds. 

There's almost always an available seat and TONS of outlets everywhere to plug in your laptop. 

Decor is kinda funky but not really in a bad way. 

The workers always seem pretty amicable, I usually deal with a younger guy when I stop by later at night and he's great! Always very busy but he keeps on top of it. Speaking of which, they're open til 10pm, which is later than any other coffee shop in the area that I'm aware of .
author: Toby F.

description: I nice place to work with large windows for light and decent drinks. The only issue I had was the restroom was out of order when I went.
author: Vincent S.

description:
The Royal Ground
A Tragicomedy

Act One
The Bus Stop 

- Scene -
 
The LED lights in the bus shelter reads 38 Geary 5 min. Stranger goes inside and gets some zucchini bread. I am hungry so I go in and get a piece of zucchini bread too. Together, in the bus shelter, we eat.

Stranger: How's yours?
Me: A little dry, but it's all right.
Stranger: Mine too.
We smile.
I turn my zucchini over, and the other side of it is covered in mold! Huge round moldy saucers on the back side!
I think to myself, "Oh god, I've already eaten quite a bit of this. I might get sick!" I show Stranger.
Stranger: You should tell them.
Me: I don't wanna tell them.
Stranger: You should, they need to know about it.
Me: Okay, I will tell them.

The lady inside reaches all the way in the back of the pile for fresher pieces of zucchini bread, hands me one. She apologizes.

In the bus shelter...

I begin to eat.
Stranger: How is it? 
Me: Much better! Wanna try it?
Stranger: No, it will only make me sad.
Me: Hee hee. 
The bus pulls up. Stranger and I sit apart. I get off earlier than her.
Me: Bye!
Stranger: Bye!

- End Scene - 

Act Two
The Toilet

- Scene -

On the toilet...

Me: Why me? Why oh why? Oh cruel world, I've given them my business so many times before, and have tipped well every time. Why do they repay me by taking their chances on days old, moldy bread for $1.65? Why do they charge the same price for perfectly fresh bread and now I have the squirts! Such squirts! My butt is burbling! I am squirting! Squirting! I have been squirting watery squirts for 24 hours! Running to the toilet everywhere I turn  - Costco, the fabric store, my friend's house, everywhere I turn - Why why why?!

- End Scene - 

- Finis -
author: Josephine L.

description: Decent coffee, decent sweets, definitely a good selection of food and the sandwiches are awesome for the price. My favorite is the Lox bagel with capers and tomatoes and onions. Yum. I'll say the atmosphere is much better than the busy nearby Starbucks (along with better pricing and better food). I work in the area and spend a lot of time studying after work. This place is definitely my go-to. No complaints here!
author: Anna K.

description: A nice place to hang out on the weekend and read the paper, grab a quick bite or get some work done (free wifi). Nice hardworking people and comfy couches. So much better than Starbucks!  I'd much rather support this type of coffee shop. It's on the corner has huge windows that get good light and has high ceilings. Very comfy.
author: Priscilla C.

description:
One of my new favorite spots to go out and study at.  Been here a few times now and I've always left happy...largely because of the free wi-fi!  Yes, parking can be a pain, but really...where is it not in the city?  In places that you want to be at least...

But really, the workers have always been pretty friendly, and the prices are pretty reasonable.  I have yet to try their sandwiches, but their salad was pretty good and their smoothies really hit the spot back in the SF "summer" during the heat wave.

Definitely one of the top places to go on my list when I need to get out and study/work.
author: Mike L.

description:
I am no coffee connoisseur, so I would not be able to tell you how good my iced latte was.  I can only inform you that it was relatively cheap and made promptly.

The spacious interior, combined with multiple tables and free wi-fi, made it more inviting than the Starbucks that is a few blocks away.  The atmosphere was neither deathly silent nor bustling with conversation, which created a relaxed vibe that was conducive to a hushed meeting.

However, in the couple hours that we were there, there was little turnover in terms of customers.  This does not bode well for the times when I am unable to find a seat immediately.
author: Andrew M.

description:
On a rainy day and a need for wi-fi in the Richmond District of SF, this place is an oasis! 

FREE WI-FI.

$2 for a pot of tea. (Big pot! Even BIGGER than my beloved Sack's!)

Cute tables, mural, lighting, couches.

And outlets!

Now if only they offered their own home-baked or a better selection of more appealing baked goods...then it would be near perfect! (Definitely Costco mini brownies and "Aussie" cakes I see there!).
author: Gail N.

description: Soooooo good!  Tiffany Y. and I were looking for somewhere close to grab a sammy and Royal Ground was perfect.  Tiffany Y. had been here before, but she said it was even better than she remembered!  They have a great selection of sandwiches, salads, smoothies and delightful little treats.  I got the veggie sammy and it was loaded with great, fresh veggies.  The staff here is friendly and the ambiance is really enjoyable!
author: Tara B.

description:
Yelp hath betrayed me. I have to say this was the biggest miss for me of any place I've found on Yelp. 3.5 stars is my cutoff for seeking a place out and I'm almost always satisfied by such places, but this one missed the mark.

I went to Royal Grounds for a light dinner and got the California sandwich. It tasted like the worst "deli" sandwich that you get at a convenience store. The turkey was that bland, plastic texture deli meat that you get in the prepared foods aisle at a grocery store rather than the deli counter. The cheese was the individually wrapped slice variety. It's rare for me not to finish even a questionable meal after it has been purchased, but for this sandwich I made an exception.

I admit the ambiance was nice and the free wi-fi is convenient, but I base my ratings on food and drink. If for some reason I find myself in Outer Richmand in the future, I'll steer way clear of this place.
author: Adam B.

description:
This is where Jonathan and I had met for the first time for coffee ( I got hungry so i end up buying their pesto chicken sandwich, YUMMM!!). And this past Aug. 1st we had gone there to relive the memories. It was time well spent. 

This cafe has a great atmosphere, not so noisy other than the Muni coming and going but it's not the hazy, chaotic atmosphere like Starbucks. I LOVE the mural inside. If there was a place like this in Corvallis i'd be here everyday to study or even to read. The service is great here and the staff is very friendly. I love the creativity of the furniture there. Although I did order a chai tea and it didn't taste like the way I was expecting it to. eek. Oh well it's alright, I really didn't know what to drink and coffee wasn't really on my mind. :T

I don't know how well the internet works here nor have I tried since I've only been here a few times. But every time I've been here has been a memorable and comfortable time. :)
author: Marie G.

description:
I love outside seating evening. But this cafe always keep smokers, several Russian middle aged guys playing game. EVERY evening and night!!

These guys are heavy smokers. My lung and health will be affected. I hate smell of cigarette. The cafe management is absolutely aware of those guys smoking by glass window. Their allowance is completely illegal in this city. If they allow this, I will definitely file a complaint to the city health department.
author: AI T.

description: Hands down, worst place to get coffee and food in the city.  If this was the only place in the City to get coffee, I probably go without.
author: Monica B.

description:
This is probably one of the worst cappuccinos in the Richmond. Seriously I asked for a dry double and watched the barista spoon me a half a cup of foam, which is fine, and then pour two cups of milk into the cup. Did I not tip enough or what?!

Look the bottom line is if you order a cappuccino, single or double, if the barista grabs a 16 or 20 oz cup then you know you're hosed. I'd like some coffee with that warm milk please! The only perk is a pleasant atmosphere and dark interior... oh and free wi-fi never hurts.
author: Len S.

description: Love this place, near our apartment and very cozy place to hang out or work.
author: Iman F.

description:
It's not often that I find myself looking for coffee in the Richmond at 9:30 am on a Thursday.  Today, however, I snuck out of the office to run an errand, and I found myself in the outer Richmond.  It was 2 hours past my First Cup of Coffee O'Clock, and I was getting cranky.  I was thinking about finding a Starbucks, but suddenly I saw Royal Ground Coffee.  It was time to pull over.

I have to say that Royal Ground Coffee holds a special place in my heart.  Please forgive me if this review is affected by my sappy nostalgia, but I just can't help it.  When I was in my late teens, my friend used to work here.  I don't know how many evenings I spent hanging out by the counter, drinking free or heavily discounted coffee and talking with my friend.  Remember Sumitomo Bank on the next block?  That's where I got my very first car loan for my 1996 Saturn SL2.  Boy, what a piece of crap that car was!  Finally, when I tutored MBA hopefuls, I brought my GMAT books and held my teaching sessions right here.

But I digress.

It's a small coffee house that wants to make you feel special.  It's a perfect coffee house for those who love to hate Starbucks.  It even feels cozy and hip, although it really isn't hip at all.  It reminds me of small, independent coffee houses on the East Coast.

They have a few small wooden tables with painted tabletops.  They also have two couches with duvet covers featuring jazzy floral prints.  Add a nice plastic cover, and you could be at your grandma's house.  The wooden floorboards are creaky, creating an interesting ambiance.  The indoor electric water fountain is a new addition.  Talk about class!

What I love about this place is the huge windows and free wi-fi.  The crowd waiting for the 38 bus provides all the entertainment you need, should you forget your laptop.  They also have 3 desktops set up, and I think they are actually free.  Maybe not though.

As for the drinks and the food, it's just your regular traditional coffee house fare.  Their house coffee is pretty good; that's what I usually get.  The pastries are passable, at least Starbucks quality or better.  The biscotti is pretty good.  Again, I wouldn't come here for the food, I'd come here to enjoy the ambiance, the free wi-fi and a good conversation.

The staff here changes all the time, but they're consistently polite without being overly chatty or chummy.  They won't engage you in a conversation, but they won't yell at you, either.  If you're looking for the barista to be your BFF, I'd say go elsewhere.

Royal Ground is an A-OK place that would get 3 enthusiastic stars, if it hadn't been for my sappy stories.  So . . . Four stars it is!
author: Yan G.

description:
they've got a really wide choice of seating, which is important for me: desks, comfy couches, basket weave chairs.
Plus public computers, free wifi for 90 mins if you have a laptop.
Prices are comparable to Starbucks, but with many more options of food. Also they've got tea pots for tea lovers, which is so cool especially for me - i always get it.
It is never empty but you always can get a place to sit.
Power outlets everywhere.
close at 10pm
P.S. interior is very unique (they even have fountains inside with lots of plants) - check this place out!
author: Margaryta M.

description: I don't like it at all. Lame coffee, mean baristas, and a giant glass case of meat and weird food. Not my cup of tea (haha). Total bummer since I live very nearby. After a few attempts at convincing myself of its palatable nature, I decided that was a waste of time and instead have become very comfortable vehemently disliking this particular business.
author: Zoey S.

description:
I really like the comfort and convenience of a deli that always has seats, always has sandwiches, and never disappoints. This is not a fancy place, it doesn't have to be. 
Sandwiches are one of the simple pleasures in life. I don't even go there for coffee, although I hear it is good. 
My basic food groups would be meat and cheese and bread, if I could magically remove the type 2 diabetes and potential obesity that would eventually ensue from living in this manner. 
Moral of the story: this corner cafe makes it easy to grab a good meal at a reasonable price. They have vegan foods as well as quality omnivore selections on the menu, and I have always had a very pleasant experience there.
author: Schuyler W.

description:
What a cozy spot. The only downside is that the staff is a 'bit blah and ekh (both of those are very reasonable adjectives, thank you very much!). I ordered an Italian soda and I couldn't stick the straw in my drink, because there was a HUGE ice cube in the middle! After they crushed the ice, half of my drink was gone! So like I said, the staff is "blah" and "ekh" and possibly even "eh." However, aside from the ICEBERG in my drink, the atmosphere is adorable and it's a great place to study because the coffee shop is pretty quiet. Also, they have free wifi and plenty of outlets. :)

Fyi, good luck finding the light switch to the bathroom. Oh, you'll know what I mean when you get there...and you might be tempted to use the flashlight they give you, which is attached to the keys to the bathroom. Don't worry, the flashlight is not the alternative to a light switch, haha.
author: Narina A.

description:
This is a good cafe that has become annoying through no fault of its own.
It is really irritating when you want to buy a cup of coffee and sit down when all the seats are taken by people and their laptop computer.

Seriously. People buy a small coffee then spend 2 hours or longer lounging there with their laptop in front of them, pretending that they're doing something serious. As a result I can't sit down for 10 minutes because there are no seats.

Its a coffee shop, its not your lounge or library. Go home and stalk people on myspace or facebook in the privacy of your own house.
author: Monkey C.

description:
Where should I begin?  Should it be when I called to ask if they had wifi and they hung up on without answering me?  Or maybe it should be after I called back thinking that I just got disconnected, and then after asking again, being shouted at that, YES, they have free wifi, and was then hung up on AGAIN.

Maybe it should be when I ordered a coffee and slice of apple pie and they literally forgot about my order, which had to be pretty tough considering there weren't that many other people in the place.  

On the upside, the coffee is good and the pie was tasty.  I won't be coming back here anytime soon.
author: Adam E.

description:
I live really close by so I like it mainly for convenience and the free wi-fi. It's usually pretty busy, but there are many places to sit. Normally when I go to a new coffee shop I'll default to a regular coffee or a chai the first time. I didn't think one could really mess up a chai, but it is UNDRINKABLE here. Their coffee is slightly better.  The apple cider is good, and my usual drink is a raspberry fruit smoothie.

As far as food goes, I like the scones, and the BLT and lox bagels aren't bad.

Prices are reasonable, and you can use Credit/Debit if you spend more than $10 (I think, or maybe it's $5).
author: Jen M.

description:
Ohhhhh....Royal Ground Coffee. I'm sorry for calling you Royal Exchange, that's some burger bar in FiDi. You don't even serve burgers. And you shouldn't, because then you wouldn't be a coffee house. You would be some weird cafe place that serves burgers instead of healthy salads & other snacks. 

Truth be told, though...Your food isn't all that great. It could actually use some work. You have all the right ingredients for yummy, but somehow you just can't put it together. And your Chai tea!?! What's up with that? I've resolved never to order a Chai tea from you again, mainly because you have a problem with burning the Soy milk. Maybe you should learn a few lessons from Blue Danube? Just sayin'...

So I've ripped on you enough for being kinda mediocre, but you do exceed in a few very important areas:

1. Free Wireless
2. Comfortable Couches
3. Courteous Staff

And with that, I will still give you 4 stars...you really just need to work on the menu & train your employees a little better.

I probably won't see you as much in the future, but if my home wireless ever breaks down...You are the first place I will visit.
author: matt m.

description: Love the huge windows and no matter where you sit you get the view of Geary Street (if you like people watching). I also like how they have a mini water fountain in the corner and a lot of plants all over the place. Coffee is good, and their sandwiches are very fresh and delicious. I like their English-wich and Denver-wich. It is one of my favorite coffee shops in the city.
author: J L.

description:
When my daily coffeehouse is closed, California Grind, I come here to relax and do some work. My roommate and I like coming here a lot because of a few reasons. It's a little livelier than our fav on 17th and California, the internet is now FREE, the "California" sandwich is one of my favorite things and the girls who work there are extremely friendly and cute. They recognize me now and know exactly what I like and how I like it. In fact, I just got done meeting the owner who is interested in displaying some of my photography next month. 
Definitely one of my favorite Richmond District hang-outs!
author: Gabriel R.

description:
I like to run my mouth about the evils of chain coffee houses as much as the next person. But I'm a hypocrite when it comes to my neighborhood Royal Ground. I hit this place up at least three times a week. For a chain establishment, it's got character --- it's casual and cozy, with big fluffy couches perfect for those who want to hunker down and compute with a warm beverage. The wall murals are a bit cheesy, but the light is soft, and the corner storefront windows are enormous and ideal for people watching on a foggy Richmond evening. The staff is cheerful, they let you linger even past closing, and they make a darn good soy chai (my drink of choice). 

It doesn't feel like a chainy place, I guess is what I'm saying... The best part? They've got free wireless. And I only recently realized what a rarity that is. 

My first home in San Francisco was in Upper Haight, and I had the luxury of several great coffee houses on my strip with free wireless --- Rockin' Java and Coffee 2 the People being my favorites. But I've since grown wiser for the wear; free wireless is hard to come by in this town. Recently I was in a sterile, tile-floored Starbuck's in the Castro where I was absolutely appalled that they wanted to charge me for wireless, on top of the exorbitant price of my soy chai. Even otherwise top-notch (in my opinion) joints like Blue Danube on Clement haven't learned to share the WiFi love...

So a few weeks ago they opened a Peet's on Geary and 16th, one block from my Royal Ground. The joint that occupies the circle of chain coffee house hell just above Starbuck's. In comparison, Royal Ground only looks better. Viva la free wireless!
author: Lisa T.

description:
This is a chain. 
This is a chain???

I was in another Royal Ground (I shall leave the location nameless as to protect its identity....oh, hell, no I won't...it was the one on POLK, did you get that? POLK), and there was a huge hole in the floor outside the bathroom.....WTF?? Where is the quality control?? That being said, I decided that I really was not a huge fan of Royal Ground since the basics, like not falling into the foundation of a building, making tasty coffee, service with a smile (okay, fine, I'm not picky....at least without a scowl) were not a big concern of this chain.

Imagine my surprise when I walked into the Geary location and they had a floor...yes, you heard me right, they actually had a fully intact floor!  I only got a sparkling water, as the thought of getting coffee here again scares me still. You need to work up to these things, you know....baby steps. They even made a joke when they served me, and *gasp* smiled. 

I came here with my Mac twin Lisa W. so we could geek out and she could teach me how to use this thing (yes, I am a recent PC convert). They have free Wifi, so this location worked well for my tutoring session (thanks Lisa). It has been decided that there will be more, larger, Mac parties here in the future....and I think I am okay with this. I  may even try the coffee next time.  I hear it is pretty good.
author: Drue C.

description:
I love this place because it is so unassuming.  The coffee is good, strong and full of flavor. The price is decent too.  I even buy coffee beans for home since i no longer live in S.F. sob!  But I am here more than home anyway so that's okay. : )
Free wi fi is a plus.  I love sitting by the window and people watch.
author: Gloria H.

description:
I am a recent avid fan of finding the cafe w/ a perfect combination of studying atmosphere + variety of delicious coffee, although a place could easily win me over w/ a yummy foamy latte, which this place has, as well as *delicious* apple cider with cinnamon sticks when I've reached my caffeine intake limit.  This place is my favorite without fail, with its plenty of outlets, free wifi, nicely sized tables to fit two people w/ two laptops, and extremely friendly barristas who seem to know a whole bunch of happy repeat customers and what time they usually come and what they usually order!  Coming here on Sundays is best, for free metered parking on the street.

This place also has great lighting from the many wall-length windows, and the bus stop right outside the place makes for great people watching. A lot of people come out here to study together so I always bring my ipod in case some people are studying algebra together two feet away. In the evening the lighting gets dim but not unbearably so since I'm always on my laptop, and on one evening I even had a sighting of perhaps some knitting club -- 6 women knitting baby booties or scarves and just chatting about nothing in particular.  Only in SF...

They also have a fine selection of bagels, pastries, salads, sandwiches, and even quiche, although I haven't tried any of them b/c there are just so many food options on Geary.  The pumpkin cream cheese muffin and the banana bread aren't spectacular but they go well with my coffee.
author: Erica Y.

description:
If I had lived in the area, this place would have had a definite potential to become my 'office' away from home or office. Lots of windows and light. Comfy chairs. Free wireless. Descent food. Excellent cappuccino. Colorful, welcoming interior. 

As of now,  a great stop on my way strolling along the ocean, Golden Gate  Park and the streets of the city ...  A couple across is engaged in a serious conversation in Russian. Pity I cannot join in ... Perhaps they are lucky I can't...
author: Rob R.

description:
Coffee is pretty tasty (even the house coffee which I don't usually drink) and I don't usually have to wait too long for a table (it's easier to draw that way).
The shop has a cozy atmosphere, if you can block out the sound of altered crotch-rockets and the occasional very odd character.

But DON'T, I say DON'T eat the food. It's almost inedible. The brownies were like mini bricks!

And bring cash because they don't take cards and the ATM in the shop will butt-rape you with fees.
author: Jenn H.

description:
Walked into Royal Ground Coffee on a Friday night, about to meet with Mellie P. to gossip about men and life.

The cafe was dim yet lively. An ample display of teas, coffees, sweet treats...all so very inviting. I couldn't quite decide what I wanted. It was 8pm and I did not want to become caffeinated for fear of staying up all night and not having enough energy for work the next morning....

Warm apple cider sounded delicious though, so I ordered that. While I waited for my drink (it was prepared slowly yet so carefully and with love *heart*), I looked around the cafe to check out the space/clientele. Too bad, while I was looking around, I must have caught the "eye" of a crazy dude sitting on the couch. He noticed me immediately and kept waving at me when I looked at his direction. Oy! Dock one star for the creepy man.

Once I received my drink, I proceeded to sit down (far away from creepy man) and chatted with Mellie P. for a good bit. Her sandwich looked/smelled yummy, and I just felt happy sipping on the warm apple cider and observing Geary Blvd on a Friday evening. The calm of Royal Ground Coffee was all I needed for the end of the week.

I am hoping next time I go, said-creepy guy will not be there to wave at me again....
author: Helene K.

description:
Some how not many of the coffees stand out to me here. Pretty much white mocha, white hot chocolate...Green tea frappe...Avocado frappe. And today the lady was very nice and I asked for a Green tea Avocado frappe and she made one for me, but then again it was like 4 dollars. But still good either way since the last place I got it at was pushed out of business by Quicklys...(Roar franchises like those, it's the Asian Starbucks!) 

But free wi-fi! I haven't used it yet but I shall soon since I'm doing 16 units in college. But my friend comes here since it's close to our houses and he studies his butt off before exam time and it seems to work for him here. He spends whole day there and passes his exams. So there's a good aura around it with studying. I also use to see alot of my studious classmates from high school sit in here. Maybe residual smart-ness will be blessed upon you. (^_^)

Overall good for a neighborhood cafe, nice atmosphere. Two nice big couches and plenty of seats.
author: Kimberly S.

description: I met a group of friends here and I must say that this is a charming place to grab coffee and a bite to eat! They had a great choice of coffee, tea, and baked goods. The service was very friendly and attentive. This is also a great place to sit down and work. In fact, our group was there for more than four hours! This place definitely is going to repeat visits from us.
author: Chelsea J.

description:
Pluses:

-Good seating: you can pick from couches or tables, and the ledge by the tables by the front windows is so so handy. Lazy-asses like me don't have to put all this effort into reaching for their backpacks all the way on the floor.

-Free wi-fi and lots of outlets. Pretty much one under each table by the walls.

-Only a $5 credit card minimum. 

-Hot chocolate is just sweet enough, and foamy. *But* they used whipped cream from a can, boo.

-I'm eating this pumpkin pie right now, though, and it's creamy and cinammony and perfect. 

Minuses:

-Spinach/mushroom quiche is terribly bland. Don't order it!

-Wifi has kicked me off twice in the past two hours.
author: Le V.

description:
SO GOOD I MOVED NEARBY. AND FREE WIFI. I DIDN'T INTEND TO RHYME. GOD DAMNIT, I DID IT AGAIN!

a gigantic slection of drinks, including thai iced tea [which melts faces] and a great staff make this place worth coming to. the music is mellow and not all trip-hoppy or "worldly" like starbucks.

honestly, prices for coffee are pretty universal, and i'm withdrawing from ice-based drinks so this 'traditional' non-traditional coffee shop does me very well. 

it's so good that it was part of the reason i moved to the neighborhood! they even have free wifi. which also melts faces, but not as much as the thai iced tea.

i'm there at least three times a week, doing writing or finishing up work. there aren't very many other filipino people in the richmond. unless they go to USF.

[and bonus points if you ever understand my gaming references]
author: Charles C.

description:
My review is mainly based on the environment.  If you look at many of the coffee shops in this area (Park Presidio to 25th Ave in the Outer Richmond), many of them lack natural light.  This one is the exception.  It's on the corner of the street so it gets lots of natural light that makes the place more cheerful.  The place has a selection of sandwiches, quiches, and cookies to choose from.

It's a big coffee shop for the neighborhood, but it's busy.  Don't expect to get a prime seat next to the window all the time.  You might have to sit on the couch (sharing with another person) or middle table, and wait for a window table to open up.

As for the coffee, it's good.  But it's not as good as French or Italian coffee shops downtown.

It's a good place to sit down, read/study, and do computer work (and even talk to strangers).  They play XM satellite radio so you won't get hit with radio commercials.  

Other points: The free WiFi is a little spotty.  Most of the time it works, but sometimes it doesn't.  I don't go to the coffee shop to surf the Net, but others might find it essential.
author: Fred S.

description:
The free wifi gives that crowded silence feeling you get from riding the bus during commute hours. Isn't it funny that you can have 50 people standing armpit-to-armpit, trying their best to ignore their present surrounds, and nary a peep from anyone?

Anyway, same vibe. Decent salads. You do have to wait a bit for them because people are hardly coming here for the food, so there's some prep work involved. I mention salads particularly because there's nowhere to get a good salad in the Richmond beyond Park Presidio and I do this as a public service. You're welcome.
author: Stacy J.

description:
"Rev up the Lincoln
And let's get to drinkin'
Some Caffeino...
CAFFEINO!"
I was humming the chorus to that Smashmouth song, Padrino (off Fush You Mang) as I walked up Polk to grab a bunch of coffees for my bro Mike L., who's laid up after wrecking himself on his motorbike, his girlfriend Natasha, who's so cool I should just call her Alaska, and myself and my addiction to caffeine that I feel absolutely no shame over. 

Mike had suggested I walk the extra couple blocks for Royal Ground quality, and I figured since I haven't been to SF in about 18 years (besides the 6 hours I was here to play the Red Devil Lounge last Sep. -- see my Red Devil Lounge review), I should go ahead and have myself a look around at Mike's neighborhood.

Royal Ground only takes cash. Fortunately there's an ATM machine next door, but for chrissakes we're in th 21st century. I have miles to earn. Let me pay with plastic please! (ooooOOooo alliteration!)

There were the customary 5-6 patrons sitting behind their square-headed girl-/boy-friends, soaking in the free Wi-Fi. The barrista made up our coffees (drips with room for me and Mike, a triple soy latte for Natasha. Whoops, I forgot the shot of vanilla, sorry girl!). The fellow who walked in after me was a regular, and totally friendly. I like when a place has the atmosphere and/or quality to get friendly regulars in. We chatted for a moment, then I sweetened/creamed up my coffee (which of course always makes me mumble, 'I like my coffee black, like my men'... thanks Airplane!)

The barrista handed me a carry tray, awesome. I moseyed on back down the hill sipping my coffee and keeping the other two cups from splashing everywhere. Coffee was good. 

CAFFEINO!
author: Will L.

description:
Great place to hang out and take advantage of the free wi-fi. They seem to be pretty lenient on how long you stay. There are several tables, electrical outlets and even sofas for you to chill. 

This location is run by a few Asian ladies who are nice enough and efficient with orders. The coffee and pastries are standard. They also serve breakfast sandwiches, regular sandwiches and salads. Prices are all very reasonable ($5-$7).
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
Has gotten pretty bad there. Dont know what happened. They used to have the best white mocha ever there, now they burn all of the espresso drinks and there are constantly flies inside.

Shame.
author: Brett P.

description: So this place is kind of run down and old... But it makes for a good studying cafe since the tables and chairs are so hard that it's impossible to fall asleep without being uncomfortable. There's free wifi, which is a plus. There are a few couches off to the side of the cafe, which a group of old men occupied for the entire night as I studied. The drinks were alright, nothing special. If you're a student, this is a good place to study without spending too much money.
author: Lily Z.

description:
I spent a couple of hours here... started with some domestic tea (I'm a creature of habit and went with the one I buy for home - Madagascar Roobios Vanilla Red Twinings - or something like that) and I didn't try the coffee because I'd already had some that morning.  Anyway, the tea is served in a 16 oz pint glass with a long-handled ice tea spoon and a cardboard insulator to prevent a hand burn.  SOrt of weird, but okay whatever.  I thought glass was a bad choice for hot liquids, but I'm not an expert.

Anyway, this place has the typical long bench with pillows and tables etc., but what makes it unique is the back room, which I like to refer to as a "STUDY ROOM."  I ventured back with my tea and bag and the girls perched on a couch gave me a look, assumably because my breathing or walking was causing too much of a ruckus.  Sor-ry.

I went back up front and sat, pulled out my laptop and tried to logon to their wireless, agreeing to pay the 5 bucks or whatever for unlimited.  Their wireless provider is crap - I tried to put my credit card through 5 different times and it kept telling me that my first name was missing.  So, I jumped on someone else's wifi for free.  Can't say I didn't try to be a good patron.

I bought a falafel sandwich right before the rush and it was fantastic.  Wrapped in foil, not too much tahini... freshly made and hot.  The senior to my left struck up a conversation about my laptop and his eyesight.  He talked and I listened... about the Reagan administration and how he wrote several speeches for Reagan, the "This is Your Brain on Drugs" PSA concept, and a speech for Arnold, expressed his admiration for Rudy Guiliani, the miracle of zinc, getting out to exercise, the Constitution, how folks should be tested with 3 questions at the voting booth before they should be allowed to vote and so on.  I got the impression that he might be a regular there as a few folks said hello to him.  If you see John, say hello.

And I had a great experience here.  The food is good, the company is great, and the prices are low.
author: Jessica M.

description: Ample amount of outlets, but my latte smelled like gym socks.  Don't know why, but it was very off-putting.  Bathrooms are gross.
author: k h.

description:
Decent selection of food & drinks. Got a chai tea latte - it was ok... 
The free wi-fi is quite nice, and the shop is good to just sit & chill. I like the atmosphere & the staff is friendly.
author: linda t.

description:
This is my "time to get work the fuck done" coffee place. It is very conducive to sitting there for hours to write your ridiculously overdue papers for your USF independent study courses. Just sayin'.

Open until 10pm, that is, later than most of the other coffee shops that don't turn into annoying music venues at night.
author: M J.

description:
Royal Ground could've had 5 stars.. SO CLOSE! and ive never given a 5 star review. 

Por que you wonder?

- free wifi constantly kicks me off. i would always often think im the only one, something has got to be wrong with my laptop. so i sheepishly look around and i see other people's screen displaying the trying to reconnect screen. so it aint just me. yeah its free with no password and im so thankful for that, but then again... being frequently disconnected can really be annoying and inconvenient ( i had to take a timed quiz for a class and was put over my time limit because it took too long to reconnect!) but i guess it takes more than that to rid of a free wifi loving parasite like myself

- havent tried the food. i got the iced white mocha which was pretty good. only drank a 3rd because im ultra sensitive to caffeine

- I LOVE THE ATMOSPHERE! well lit so you could get smoe serious studying done

- by the bus stop

- ATM machine inside

- restrooms with key outside so there is no need to get buzzed in

- steady stream of patrons so it is good to secretly people watch behind my laptop in my self built fortress

- lots of tables

i pledge my allegiance to royal... for now.
author: Christine N.

description:
Anywhere else in the city you would pay $5.50 for a turkey sandwich and add $1 for the extra avocado, not here. The California sandwich is $4.75 and it already comes with the avocado. To this broke girl, that is one hell of a lunch deal. I forget to mention that the sandwiches are TASTY.
